alert.note: Alert for Wheeler (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pendleton (Northeast Oregon and Southeast Washington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 08 at 2:33PM PDT until May 11 at 10:45AM PDT by NWS Pendleton
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Oregon... John Day River at Service Creek affecting Wheeler County. For the John Day River...including Monument, John Day, Service Creek...Moderate flooding is forecast. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/pdt. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...John Day River at Service Creek. * WHEN...Until late Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 11.5 feet, * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:30 PM PDT Monday the stage was 13.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:30 PM PDT Monday was 13.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will fall to 12.7 feet late this evening. It will then rise to 12.9 feet late tomorrow evening. It will fall below flood stage early Thursday morning to 9.6 feet Saturday afternoon. It will then rise to 10.6 feet Wednesday, May 17. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 11.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.9 feet on 03/14/1983. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (5 pm PDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Tue Wed Thu John Day River Service Creek 11.5 13.1 Mon 1 pm PDT 12.9 12.1 10.9 &&
info.instruction: Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
